title: 114_hr2324
content: The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" allows for special conveyance authority regarding small parcels of national forest system land and public lands. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" defines terms like adjacent landholder, Director concerned, and eligible Federal lands parcel, which includes specific criteria for parcels of National Forest System land or public lands eligible for purchase. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" outlines criteria for eligible Federal lands parcels, including requirements such as population size, absence of existing rights, lack of exceptional resources, and non-habitat for endangered species. An exceptional resource is defined as a valuable resource needing extraordinary conservation efforts for public benefit. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" specifies criteria for eligible Federal lands, including the need for extraordinary conservation efforts to maintain valuable resources for public benefit. The Act defines terms like "Indian tribe" and "National Forest System land." The Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 excludes Forest Service-managed lands included in various designated areas from its definition of public lands. The term "public lands" excludes Bureau of Land Management-managed lands included in designated areas like national monuments, wilderness areas, and national scenic areas. The term "public lands" excludes certain designated areas like national monuments, wilderness areas, and national scenic areas. Regional Foresters are responsible for selecting eligible Federal lands parcels for conveyance based on requests from adjacent landholders or recommendations from the Bureau of Land Management or National Forest System. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of the Interior have processes in place for adjacent landholders to request to purchase eligible Federal lands parcels. The process must be consistent with other public purchase request processes and be accessible to the public online. The Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management have purchase request processes for conveying Federal land to the public. The process must be open to the public, available online within 90 days, and adjacent landholders can request to purchase National Forest System land or public lands. The Director or Regional Forester will review the request within 30 days to determine eligibility for conveyance. After receiving a request, the Director or Regional Forester will assess if the parcel meets the criteria for conveyance. If the adjacent landholder's request is rejected, a written explanation detailing the reasons for rejection will be provided, including how the parcel fails to meet the eligibility criteria and the potential impact of continued administration by the Bureau of Land Management or the Forest Service. The eligible Federal lands parcel conveyed under this section may not exceed 160 acres unless approved for additional acreage. An adjacent landholder can acquire only one parcel per year, with a limit of 160 acres. The Director or Regional Forester must approve requests for additional acreage beyond 160 acres for eligible Federal lands parcels. An adjacent landholder can acquire one parcel per year, with exceptions for parcels under 160 acres. Public notice of available parcels must be provided, even if they share boundaries with non-Federal land or multiple parcels owned by the same adjacent landholder. The notice must state the eligibility of Federal lands parcels for conveyance, whether they share boundaries with a single non-Federal parcel or multiple parcels owned by the same adjacent landholder. Sales are negotiated with single adjacent landholders and conducted through competitive bidding with multiple adjacent landholders. The sale of eligible public lands parcels that share boundaries with non-Federal landholders will be conducted through competitive bidding. Offers that do not meet the minimum consideration required may be rejected, with an opportunity for appeal. Purchasers must agree to comply with local land use ordinances and zoning plans. The Director or Regional Forester will require purchasers of eligible public lands parcels to comply with local land use ordinances and zoning plans. The conveyance of eligible Federal lands parcels will be done through a quitclaim deed. An appeals process is available if a request for selection or purchase is rejected. The Director or Regional Forester will provide an appeals process for reconsideration if a request for selection or purchase of National Forest System land is rejected. The sale of eligible Federal lands parcels will require fair market value consideration. The Director or Regional Forester will require fair market value consideration for the sale of eligible Federal lands parcels. The fair market value of a parcel will be determined by an appraisal submitted by the adjacent landholder, with the option for the Director or Regional Forester to reject and conduct another appraisal if needed. The Director or Regional Forester can reject an appraisal within 45 days. If rejected, another appraisal must be conducted within 30 days. Proceeds from land sales are collected into a special Treasury fund and distributed annually to states with over 33% federal land ownership. Funds collected from land sales are deposited into the Treasury fund and distributed annually to states with over 33% federal land ownership. States must agree to use the funds for purchasing additional eligible Federal lands parcels. States receiving funds from land sales must use the money for purchasing eligible Federal lands parcels and complying with federal requirements such as the Endangered Species Act and the National Environmental Policy Act. The purchaser is responsible for covering conveyance costs incurred. The purchaser is required to cover costs incurred for conveyance, including survey and appraisal costs, environmental documentation, and administrative costs. Any excess amount collected in advance must be refunded to the purchaser. Amounts received as reimbursement will be credited to the fund used for covering the conveyance costs. The Director or Regional Forester shall refund excess amounts to the purchaser. Amounts received as reimbursement will be credited to the fund for conveyance costs. The conveyance of eligible Federal lands should take no more than 18 months. Conveyance under this section is categorically excluded from environmental assessment requirements. The conveyance of eligible Federal lands should take no more than 18 months and is categorically excluded from environmental assessment requirements. The conveyance authority provided by this section is in addition to other sale authorities.
